metadata.title: Ni–Co bimetallic coordination effect for long lifetime rechargeable Zn–air battery

(a) SEM image of CNT. (b) SEM image, (c) TEM image, (d, e) HRTEM images, and (f) EDS mapping of CoNi–NCNT. Fig 1 Fig. 2 Composition and textural characterization. (a) XRD patterns of CoNi–NCNT. (b) Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms, and (c) corresponding pore size distribution of CNT and CoNi–NCNT. XPS fine spectrum of (d) Co 2p, (e) Ni 2p, and (f) N 1s. Fig 2 Fig. 3 ORR performance for different samples. (a) ORR polarization curves of different samples and commercial Pt/C at 1600 rpm in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution with a scan rate of 10 mV/s, and (b) corresponding Tafel slope of the polarization curves of catalysts and commercial Pt/C. (c) Chronoamperometric response of CoNi–NCNT and Pt/C for ORR at half-wave potential. (d) Cyclic stability test for CoNi–NCNT for ORR. (e) LSV curves of CoNi–NCNT at different rotation speeds with a scan rate of 10 mV/s, and (f) corresponding K–L plots. Fig 3 Fig. 4 RRDE tests for CoNi–NCNT, Co-NCNT and Pt/C. (a) Disk current density, and (b) ring current recorded in a rotating ring-disk electrode system in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH at 1600 rpm. (c) Electron transfer number, and (d) hydrogen peroxide yield calculated using the corresponding RRDE data. Fig 4 Fig. 5 ORR performance for different samples. (a) OER polarization curves of different samples, and (b) corresponding Tafel plots. (c) Chronoamperometric measurements of CoNi–NCNT and Pt/C for OER at potential of 10 mA/cm2. (d) Cyclic stability tests of CoNi–NCNT for OER. (e) Polarization curves of different catalysts for both ORR and OER. Inset is the potential gap (ΔE) between E J = 10 mA/cm2 and E 1/2 for all the catalysts. Fig 5 Fig. 6 Electrochemical performance of Zn–air battery using CoNi–NCNT. (a) Schematic illustration of the assembled Zn–air battery. (b) Photograph of the lighting bulb, and (c) open circuit potential based on CoNi–NCNT. (d) Open circuit plot of CoNi–NCNT and Pt/C-Ir/C. (e) Charging and discharging polarization curves and corresponding calculated discharge power density. (f) Typical specific capacity curves recorded at 10 mA/cm2 discharge rate. (g) Cycling performance of the battery at the charging and discharging current density of 10 mA/cm2. Fig 6 Scheme 1 Brief illustration of synthesis of CoNi–NCNT. Ni–Co bimetallic coordination effect for long lifetime rechargeable Zn–air battery Qiao Mengfei a d 1 Wang Ying a d 1 Thomas Wågberg b Xamxikamar Mamat a ⁎ Hu Xun c ⁎ Zou Guoan a Hu Guangzhi a b ⁎⁎ a Key Laboratory of Xinjiang Indigenous Medicinal Plants Resource Utilization, and Key Laboratory of Plant Resources and Chemistry in Arid Regions, Xinjiang Technical Institute of Physics and Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Urumqi 830011, Xinjiang, China Key Laboratory of Xinjiang Indigenous Medicinal Plants Resource Utilization, and Key Laboratory of Plant Resources and Chemistry in Arid Regions, Xinjiang Technical Institute of Physics and Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences Urumqi Xinjiang 830011 China aKey Laboratory of Xinjiang Indigenous Medicinal Plants Resource Utilization, and Key Laboratory of Plant Resources and Chemistry in Arid Regions, Xinjiang Technical Institute of Physics and Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Urumqi 830011, Xinjiang, China b Department of Physics, Umeå University, S-901 87 Umeå, Sweden Department of Physics Umeå University Umeå S-901 87 Sweden bDepartment of Physics, Umeå University, S-901 87 Umeå, Sweden c School of Material Science and Engineering, University of Jinan, Jinan 250022, Shandong, China School of Material Science and Engineering University of Jinan Jinan Shandong 250022 China cSchool of Material Science and Engineering, University of Jinan, Jinan 250022, Shandong, China d University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China dUniversity of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author at: Key Laboratory of Xinjiang Indigenous Medicinal Plants Resource Utilization, and Key Laboratory of Plant Resources and Chemistry in Arid Regions, Xinjiang Technical Institute of Physics and Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Urumqi 830011, Xinjiang, China. Key Laboratory of Xinjiang Indigenous Medicinal Plants Resource Utilization, and Key Laboratory of Plant Resources and Chemistry in Arid Regions, Xinjiang Technical Institute of Physics and Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences Urumqi Xinjiang 830011 China 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. The development of bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts with high efficiency, high stability, and low cost is of great significance to the industrialization of rechargeable Zn–air batteries. A widely accepted view is that the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) follow different catalytic mechanisms, and accordingly they need different active sites for catalysis. Transition metal elements have admirable electronic acceptance ability for coordinating with reactants, and this can weaken the bond energy between reactants, thus promoting the ORR or OER reactions. Herein, the ORR and OER activities of different transition metal supported nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes were systematically studied and compared. The optimal catalyst for synchronous ORR and OER was obtained by pyrolyzing melamine, cobalt nitrate, and nickel nitrate on carbon nanotubes, called cobalt–nickel supported nitrogen-mixed carbon nanotubes (CoNi–NCNT), which were equipped with two types of high-performance active sites—the Co/Ni–N–C structure for the ORR and CoNi alloy particles for the OER—simultaneously. Remarkably, the optimized CoNi–NCNT exhibited a satisfactory bifunctional catalytic activity for both the ORR and OER. The value of the oxygen electrode activity parameter, ΔE, of CoNi–NCNT was 0.81 V, which surpasses that of catalysts Pt/C and Ir/C, and most of the non-precious metal-based bifunctional electrocatalysts reported in previous literatures. Furthermore, a specially assembled rechargeable Zn–air cell with CoNi–NCNT loaded carbon paper as an air cathode was used to evaluate the practicability. As a result, a superior specific capacity of 744.3 mAh/gZn, a peak power density of 88 mW/cm2, and an excellent rechargeable cycling stability were observed, and these endow the CoNi–NCNT with promising prospects for practical application. Graphical abstract The as-prepared catalyst cobalt-nickel-supported nitrogen-mixed carbon nanotube (CoNi–NCNT) possesses active sites of Co/Ni–N–C structure and CoNi alloy nanoparticles, which endow it with excellent catalytic performances for the oxygen reduction and oxygen evolution reaction, respectively. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Bifunctional catalysis Oxygen reduction reaction Oxygen evolution reaction Carbon nanotubes Zn–air battery 1 Introduction With the increasing environmental pollution and an energy shortage caused by the heavy consumption of fossil fuels, the development of efficient, low-cost, and environment-friendly new energy technologies has great significance for the next generation of energy science and technologies [1–3]. Therefore, rechargeable metal-air batteries, fuel cells, and water splitting cells have attracted considerable interest as renewable and sustainable energy conversion technology [4–6]. However, the intrinsic sluggish reaction kinetics of oxygen electrode reaction, including the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER), severely limit their energy conversion efficiency and inhibit their commercial application [7,8]. Currently, precious metal-based catalysts are generally used in commercial oxygen electrode catalysis, where Pt- is used for acceleration of the ORR, and Ir–/Ru– is used for the OER [9]. Disappointingly, the scarcity and high cost of these noble metal materials has largely impeded the commercialization of new energy conversion technologies [10,11]. On the other hand, single precious metals generally provide only ORR or OER catalytic activity, but not both simultaneously, and fail to meet the bifunctional catalytic requirements of metal–air batteries [12]. Therefore, developing low-cost and efficient bifunctional catalysts as a substitute for precious metals has been the focus of related research [2]. Transition metals have, because of the 3d unoccupied orbitals that can accommodate foreign electrons to reduce bond strength between the OOH*/OH* intermediates, the potential for the catalytic reaction process [13]. However, there is no single kind of active center that provides the highest catalytic activity for the ORR and OER at the same time. For the ORR, metal-nitrogen-carbon (M–N–C, M = Fe, Co) materials with excellent ORR activity are considered as the most promising substitute for Pt/C. For instance, Sun et al. reported a single-atomic cobalt-embedded N-doped carbon named Co-SAS/HOPNC, which was loaded with highly dispersed isolated atomic Co–N4 active sites, and exhibited outstanding performance for ORR in an alkaline medium, in which it possessed a half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.892 V [14]. A same high performance Fe-N-C-based materials have been reported in our previous work [15]. For the OER, the closely connected metal atoms in the metal particles are more conducive to lacing the high-energy OO bond because of the formation of coordination structures between the metal atoms and the oxygen atoms [16]. According to the latest research, due to the improvement in the structural stability of the active center and the modulation of the electron cloud, bimetallic particles shows higher activity and stability when compared with monometallic atomic particles [17]. For example, Su et al. prepared bimetal FeCo nanoparticles-encapsulated nitrogen-doped graphitic carbon nanotubes (N-GCNT/FeCo), in which the FeCo alloy-induced N-doped carbon matrix exhibited a higher catalytic activity for the OER than monometallic doping of Co or Fe [18]. Generally, catalysts composed of a pure active center structure of M–N–C or alloy particles show poor charge transfer and mass transfer, so combining transitional metals with a carbon carrier should be a good plan [19]. The synergistic effects between transitional metals and carbon materials not only improve the catalytic activity, but also enhance the stability and tolerance of the active sites [20]. Mass research results demonstrate that high specific surface area, graphitization degree, and a well-defined porous structure are beneficial to improving the catalytic performance, where a high specific surface area is able to expose more active sites, a high graphitization degree can improve electron transfer to reduce reaction resistance, and a porous structure is helpful for mass transmission [21]. Keeping these in mind, cobalt-nickel-supported nitrogen-mixed carbon nanotube (CoNi–NCNT) were prepared by tailoring the transition metals cobalt and nickel, and the carbon nanotube (CNT), which exhibited highly catalytic efficiency and stability for the ORR and OER. In the synthesis of CoNi–NCNT, the metal elements Co and Ni were first coordinated with the melamine by an alcohothermal process reaction. Then, major part of the coordination structures of the metals with melamine was decomposed to form CoNi alloy particles during the pyrolysis process, whereas a small part was transformed in-situ into the M–N–C (M = Co and Ni) structure at the edge of the alloy nanoparticles. According to the comparison experiment, the high oxygen reduction activity mainly comes from the structure of Co–N–C, and the introduction of Ni can effectively adjust the electron cloud density and spin density of Co/Ni–N–C to improve the stability of the active sites and the electron transfer number. In addition, the introduced Co element modulates the electronic cloud structure of Ni, and then the alloy particles of CoNi, as the active center, endow the catalyst with superior oxygen evolution performance and excellent stability. Furthermore, its superior stability, as revealed by the rapid cyclic aging test and chronoamperometric method, make it technologically feasible, and the low-cost, unlimited raw materials make it economically feasible for large-scale applications in Zn–air batteries, or as the cathode of fuel cells. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of catalysts Firstly, 1 mM melamine, 0.5 mM Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.5 mM Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, and 0.5 g activated carbon nanotube (CNT, MREDA, US) were dissolved in 7 mL methanol and fully mixed by ultrasound. Then, the uniformly dispersed solution was added to a steel autoclave to carry out an alcohothermal process at 130 °C for 10 h. Subsequently, the mixture was filtered and dried at 90 °C. Finally, CoNi–NCNTs were synthesized by carbonization at 800 °C for 2 h under an N2 atmosphere. For comparison, control samples, labeled Co–NCNT, Ni–NCNT, Fe–NCNT, Cu–NCNT, and Mn–NCNT were prepared by adding 1 mM Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 1 mM Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, 1 mM Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, 1 mM Cu(NO3)2, or 1 mM MnSO4·H2O as the metal source, respectively, under exactly the same procedures as described above. To clearly explain the role of the different active sites, other materials, labeled Co–CNT, Ni–CNT, Fe–CNT, Cu–CNT, and Mn–CNT were prepared without melamine. 2.2 Electrochemical testing All electrochemical measurements were performed on an PGSTAT 302 N (Metrohm Auto Lab) and a standard electrochemical cell (Pine Instruments). A conventional Ag/AgCl electrode (~3 M KCl aqueous solution), and a carbon rod were served as the reference and counter electrodes, respectively. All the electrochemical data were measured in 0.1 M KOH electrolyte at an ambient temperature of 18–25 °C. Reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) calibration was carried out in the hydrogen saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolyte, in which a carbon rod and a Pt foil acted as the counter electrode and the working electrode respectively, and the Ag/AgCl as the reference electrode. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was conducted at a scan rate of 1 mV/s, and the average of two potentials at which the current crossed zero was regarded as equilibrium potential of hydrogen reaction. Thus, all electrochemical data measured against an Ag/AgCl electrode should be adjusted according to the potential conversion equation of E(RHE) = E(Ag/AgCl) + 0.973 V (Fig. S1). To prepare the working electrode, 10 µL catalysts inks (6 mg/mL), which were prepared by dispersing 6 mg of the catalysts (including Pt/C and Ir/C) in 1 mL of a solution of 1:4 (water:isopropanol) with 0.1 wt% Nafion as a binder, was load on the polished Φ5 mm rotating disk electrode (RDE, Pine Instruments). For the detailed ORR measurement process, CV curves were recorded by the an PGSTAT 302 N instrument with a sweep rate of 50 mV/s and a rotation rate 1600 rpm of RDE in the O2 or N2-saturated solution. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves were recorded at a sweep rate of 50 mV/s and a different rotation rate of 400–2025 rpm in the O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH, and the data were rectified by subtracting the background current measured under an N2 atmosphere. Chronoamperometric measurements performed at the half-wave potential of CoNi–NCNT or Pt/C were used to evaluate the durability of the catalysts. Furthermore, a cyclic aging test of 3000 cycles, recorded in the same CV experiments as above, was also used to further prove the stability of the material. For the Tafel plot, the kinetic current was calculated from the mass-transport correction for the RDE by: (1) J K − 1 = J − 1 − J L − 1 The electrons transfer number was calculated by the Koutecky–Levich (K–L) equation: (2) J − 1 = J K − 1 + J L − 1 = J K − 1 + ( B ω 1 / 2 ) − 1 (3) B = 0.62 n F C 0 D 2 / 3 υ − 1 / 6 (4) J K = nFk C 0 where J represents the measured current density; J L represents the diffusion limited current; J K represents the kinetic current density; ω represents the electrode rotation rate; B represents the slope of the K–L plots; n is the transferred electron number per oxygen molecules; F represents the Faraday constant (F = 96,485 C/mol); D represents the diffusion coefficient of O2 in 0.1 M KOH solution (D = 1.9 × 10−5 cm2/s); and υ represents the kinetic viscosity of the electrolyte (υ = 0.01 cm2/s). C 0 represents the bulk concentration of O2 (C 0 = 1.2 × 10−6 mol/cm3). The total hydrogen peroxide yield (YH2O2 (%)) and electron-transfer number (n) were determined by the rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) approach using: (5) n = 4 J D / [ J D + ( J R / N ) ] (6) Y H 2 O 2 ( % ) = 100 [ ( 2 J R / N ) / ( J D + ( J R / N ) ) ] Where J D and J R represent the voltammetric currents recorded by the disk and ring electrode, respectively. N which was determined to be 0.37, is the RRDE collection efficiency. For the detailed OER measurement process, OER tests were conducted in N2-saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolyte with sweep rates of 10 mV/s and a rotation rate of 1600 rpm. All recorded potentials were corrected with 90%IR compensation according to the E–90%IR relation, in which I represents the measured current and R represents the electrolyte ohmic resistance, which was measured by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) with the frequency range from 100 kHz to 1 Hz at an open-circuit voltage (Fig. S2). The stability was evaluated by a chronamperometry test at the potential of E J = 10 mA/cm2 with rotation rate of 1600 rpm and a cyclic stability test of 3000 cycles. 2.3 Rechargeable Zn–air battery Rechargeable zinc-air battery tests with CoNi–NCNT and Pt/C-Ir/C (50 wt% Pt/C and 50 wt% Ir/C) were performed in a laboratory-assembled electrolytic cell. The electrolytic cell was assembled with the following components: an air electrode prepared by dripping 1 mL the catalyst ink (6 mg/mL) on a 3 cm2 composite substrate of carbon cloth and Ni foam, a zinc plate as anode, and a mixed electrolyte of 6 M KOH and 0.2 M zinc acetate. The charge-discharge cycle tests of the catalysts were recorded by the PGSTAT 302 N with a two-electrode system under ambient conditions. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation and structural characterization The preparation process for CoNi–NCNT and the formation mechanism of the active sites are schematically presented in Scheme 1 . Firstly, the coordination structure of the metallic elements (Co and Ni), and the ortho-nitrogen of melamine were formed through an alcohothermal reaction and grew uniformly on the activated CNTs. Then, the coordination structure was transformed in-situ to the Co/Ni–N–C structure and alloy nanoparticles during pyrolysis at 800 °C. The Co/Ni-N–C structure and alloy nanoparticles act as the catalytic active centers for the ORR and OER, respectively. The structure, morphology, and the loaded alloy nanoparticles of CoNi–NCNT were characterized by scanning electron microscope (SEM), and high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM). In the SEM images of the CNTs (Fig. 1 (a)) and CoNi–NCNT (Fig. 1(b)), we judged that the particles that were obviously modified on the CNTs may have the resulted from the formation of CoNi alloy particles. The internal structure of CoNi–NCNT as characterized by HRTEM illustrate that the well-distributed nanoparticles consist in the interior of CNTs (Fig. 1(c)). The electron diffraction pattern of the nanoparticles with an interplanar spacing of 0.205 nm (Fig. 1(d)) is close to that of Co (0.2046 nm, PDF#89-7093) and Ni (0.2041 nm, PDF#89-7128), corresponding to the (111) planes of metallic Co and Ni [22]. Furthermore, the 0.177 nm lattice fringe of the nanoparticles (Fig. 1(e)) can be assigned to the (200) lattice planes of Co and Ni, respectively. Further energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) mapping of CoNi–NCNT clearly demonstrate that C, N uniformly distribute throughout the CNT, and that Co/Ni tend to aggregate to form alloy CoNi particles (Fig. 1(f)). For comparison, control samples of Co–NCNT and Ni–NCNT were investigated by SEM, and these show that both of Co–NCNT and Ni–NCNT possess morphologies similar with that of CoNi–NCNT (Figs. S3 and S4). The crystalline structures of CoNi–NCNT were characterized by XRD, as shown in Fig. 2 (a). The broad and high intensity peak located at 2θ = 26.1° could be fitted to the (002) plane of graphite carbon, which suggests that a high graphitization degree in CoNi–NCNT was inherited from the CNT [23]. The other three well-defined diffraction peaks at approximately 2θ = 44.2°, 51.5° and 75.9° matches well with the (111), (200), and (220) planes of metallic Co (PDF #89-7093) and Ni (PDF #89-7128), which suggests the presence of metallic Co and Ni in CoNi–NCNT [24]. Furthermore, no other peaks appear in the diffraction pattern, which helps to explain the catalytic ability of the active sites more clearly. As samples for comparison, Co–NCNT, Ni–NCNT, and CNT were also characterized by XRD, where the obvious metal peaks of Co–NCNT and Ni–NCNT prove the formation of metal particles (Fig. S5). Furthermore, the Raman spectra of CoNi–NCNT and CNT were compared to characterize the changes after metal and nitrogen modification under high temperature (Fig. S6). The higher I D /I G ratio of CoNi–NCNT relative to CNT reveals that the modification of metals and nitrogen leads to an increase in defect positions, which often act as active centers for catalysis [16]. The specific surface area and pore size distribution of the catalyst and the comparison samples were analyzed by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) theoretical models. A higher specific surface area of CoNi–NCNT of 196.66 m2/g compared with 171.28 m2/g for the CNT can be attributed to the high-temperature treatment process under 800 °C for 2 h. The similar isotherm type for CoNi–NCNT and CNTs (Fig. 2(b)) indicate their similar micro/mesoporosity structures, which is also confirmed by the SEM images (Fig. 1(a)–(c)) and the corresponding pore size distribution (Fig. 2(c)) [25]. Apparently, the pore volume of CoNi–NCNT meets the maximal value at a pore width of approximately 12.2 nm, and the mesoporous structure is conducive to improving the mass transfer and to loading more active sites. The chemical composition, element valence state, and nitrogen bonding configuration of the different catalysts were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The wide-range spectrum reveals the presence of C (96.19 at%), N (2.92 at%), Co (0.48 at%), and Ni (0.41 at%) for CoNi–NCNT, and the corresponding changes in the comparison samples (Fig. S7, Table S1). The CoNi–NCNT sample exhibits a higher nitrogen content of 2.92 at% than that of NCNT (1.81 at%), Co-NCNT (2.41 at%) and Ni-NCNT (2.13 at%), indicating that the introduction of bimetals will strengthens the interaction between the metal and nitrogen, resulting in more Co/Ni–N–C moieties formation. The high-resolution XPS spectrum of Co 2p 3/2 (Fig. 2(d)) can be split into two corresponding subpeaks for Co2+ (779.8 eV) and Co(0) (778.3 eV). Co2+ is beneficial to the formation of the Co–N–C structure, whereas Co(0) tends to aggregate to form metal particles [26]. Similarly, the peak of Ni 2p 3/2 (Fig. 2(e)) can be fitted with two components corresponding to Ni2+ (781.9 eV) and Ni(0) (778.6 eV), respectively [27,28]. Remarkably, the analytical results for both Co 2p 3/2 and Ni 2p 3/2 reveal a high-intensity reduction from Co2+/Ni2+ to Co(0)/Ni(0), implying the formation of CoNi alloy. Furthermore, the high-resolution N 1 s spectra of CoNi–NCNT were decomposed into four components (Fig. 2(f)), pyridinic nitrogen (Py-N), pyrrolic nitrogen (Pyr-N), graphitic nitrogen (Gr–N), and oxidized nitrogen (Ox-N), which were located at 398.8, 399.7, 401.1, and 403.3 eV, respectively [29]. To obtain a deeper understanding of the relationship between the bonding environment of the doped N and the ORR catalytic activity of the materials, the N 1s spectra of NCNT, Co–NCNT, Ni–NCNT, and CoNi–NCNT are compared in Fig. S8. According to recent reports, Py-N and Gr-N serve as oxygen adsorption sites because of their excellent electron-accepting abilities, whereas Pyr-N and Py-N tend to form a metal coordination structure (M–Nx) to promote the ORR [30]. As shown in the Fig. S8, the obvious Pyr-N peak and enhanced Py-N peak can be attributed to the formation of Co–Nx and Ni–Nx, where Co–Nx possesses an inferior energy barrier for oxygen dissociation to reduce the ORR overpotential [31]. 3.2 Evaluating the electrocatalytic activity of all samples The ORR catalytic activity of the as-prepared catalysts was first evaluated by CV in N2 or O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution (Fig. S9). Obvious O2 reduction peaks located at 0.62 V, 0.62 V, 0.62, 0.76, 0.68, and 0.72 V (vs. RHE) can be attributed to the ORR process for Ni–CNT, Ni–NCNT, Co–CNT, Co–NCNT, CoNi–CNT, and CoNi–NCNT, respectively. Interestingly, the redox peak of Co tends to be flat in comparison with the CV curves of CoNi–NCNT and Co–NCNT, implying that the doped Ni can effectively enhance the stability of Co, which may contribute to the improvement of catalytic activity and stability. Then, the LSV polarization curves (Fig. 3 (a)) of all samples were compared to investigate the relationship between ORR activity and different active sites. The higher on-set potential (E onset) of 0.88 V and half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.81 V of CoNi–NCNT indicate its superior catalytic activity. The similar LSV polarization curve types and similar on-set potentials (E onset) of Co-NCNT and CoNi–NCNT imply that Co–N–C maybe the main active center for ORR. To further verify the role of Co–N–C in the ORR, we compared the LSV curves of NCNT, Co–CNT, and Co–NCNT in Fig. S10, in which CNT doped with Co or N elements alone show inferior ORR catalytic activity. However Co–NCNT co-doped with Co and N depicts superior catalytic activity, where the obviously enhanced catalytic activity is obtained from Co–N–C structure. However, compared to Co–NCNT, CoNi–NCNT results in a more positive half-wave potential (E 1/ 2 = 0.81 V), and an enhanced steady-state diffusion current density (J L = 5.8 mA/cm2), which can be attributed to the fact that the Ni doping improves the electron cloud density and spin density of the Co–N–C active structure, implying a more efficient electron transfer pathways (Fig. 3(a)). Meanwhile, the much smaller Tafel slope of 56 mV/dec of CoNi–NCNT compared with that of Co-NCNT (61 mV/dec) uncover a more efficient ORR process (Fig. 3(b)). Further, chronoamperometric measurements were performed to evaluate the durability of the Co–NCNT, CoNi–NCNT and commercial Pt/C (20 wt%) in Fig. 3(c). After 24 h ORR tests at the applied half-wave potential, there was only a trivial degradation of catalytic activity in CoNi–NCNT, consisting of a 9% loss of its initial current density, whereas the Co-NCNT suffered a 22% loss and commercial Pt/C 26% loss. The current of Co-NCNT decreased significantly in the first 6 h, while that of CoNi–NCNT did not, which can be attributed to the enhanced stability of ORR active centers after the introduction of Ni. In addition, a rapid cyclic aging test was performed to further characterize the catalytic stability of CoNi–NCNT, in which a minor negative potential shift of 20 mV after 3000 cycles proved its long-term durability (Fig. 3(d)). The Damjanovic model illustrates that the ORR may involve a direct 4e− pathway for O2 to H2O, a sequential 2e− reduction of O2 to H2O2, or a parallel pathway including 2e− and 4e−. LSV curves measured at different speeds ranging from 400 rpm to 2025 rpm were employed first to analyze the ORR kinetics of CoNi–NCNT (Fig. 3(e)). The electron transfer number calculated via the Koutecky–Levich (K–L) equation at a potential ranging from 0.75 V to 0.55 V indicates an almost 4e− reduction reaction of oxygen to hydroxyl (Fig. 3(f)). Then, an RRDE system was used to further investigate the reduction mechanism of CoNi–NCNT (Fig. 4 ). By analyzing the recorded data of the disk (Fig. 4(a)) and ring current (Fig. 4(b)), a low H2O2 yield below 5% (Fig. 4(c)) and an average number of electrons transferred of 3.93 (Fig. 4(d)) over the kinetics limiting region were obtained, which is far ahead of that 15.6% and 3.68 of Co-NCNT, implying that the introduction of Ni can effectively promote the 4e− transfer path due to the modulation of the electron cloud density at ORR active centers. For the OER catalytic activity of the as-prepared catalysts, LSV tests were performed in N2-saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolyte at a rotation rate of 1600 rpm and a sweep rate of 10 mV/s (Fig. 5 (a)). Obviously, the CoNi–NCNT showed the highest OER catalytic activity when compared with the comparison samples. A low OER potential of 1.62 V was obtained for CoNi–NCNT at a current density of 10 mA/cm2 (namely E J = 10 mA/cm2 = 1.62 V). Furthermore, the Tafel slopes of the polarization currents were calculated to evaluate the OER performance, in which a lower value for the Tafel slope corresponded to a higher catalytic efficiency [32]. As shown in Fig. 5(b), the CoNi–NCNT has a Tafel slope of 67 mV/dec, which is considerably lower than the 130 mV/dec slope for Co–NCNT, the 128 mV/dec for Ni-NCNT, and the 221 mV/dec for Ir/C. To identify the catalytic effect of different active sites on the OER, we performed several comparison experiments shown in Fig. S10. By comparing the OER activity of different catalysts, we concluded that Ni metal particles possess high intrinsic activity for the OER; meanwhile, the addition of Co and N can effectively improve the stability of Ni to reduce the over-potential for the OER. Furthermore, the chronoamperometric measurements shown in Fig. 5(c) and the rapid cyclic aging test in Fig. 5(d) reveal that CoNi–NCNT has a better long-term stability for OER than Ni–NCNT. For a more intuitive evaluation of bifunctional catalyst activity, we calculated the potential gap ΔE (between E J = 10 mA/cm2 and E 1/2) of all the catalysts based on the LSV records of the ORR and OER [33]. The lowest ΔE of 0.81 V, for CoNi–NCNT, indicated better bifunctional activity than other control samples (Fig. 5(e)). The superior bifunctional activity of CoNi–NCNT could be attributed to the following reasons. First, the Co–N–C obtained by the pyrolysis of Co and melamine has high intrinsic activity for the ORR. Second, the doped Ni improves the electron cloud density and spin density of the Co/Ni–N–C active structure, which endows CoNi–NCNT with a more efficient ORR pathway. Third, the CoNi alloy possesses high intrinsic activity for the OER, additionally, the N doping further improves its performance. Fourth, CNT as the support of the active centers possess a high specific surface area on which to load active sites, a favorable pore structure to promote mass transfer, and a well-defined graphite phase to boost electronic transfer [34]. To elaborate on the coordination of transition metals with melamine, further experiments were carried out. As depicted in Fig. S11, after doping with N, the activity of Fe–NCNT is obviously improved compared with Fe–CNT, whereas the activity of Cu–NCNT and Mn–NCNT shows only a slight increase. It fits well with previous studies that Fe–N–C shows high activity for the ORR. However, the inferior activity of Fe–NCNT compared with Co–NCNT (Fig. S12) can be attributed to the instability of the Fe–N coordination, and can be explain by the Irving–Williams Series (Fig. S13). Furthermore, the comparisons in Tab. S1 further prove it a promising candidate for application in Zn–air batteries as a bifunctional electrocatalyst. 3.3 Zn–air cell test To evaluate the bifunctional catalytic activity of CoNi–NCNT, we constructed a charge and discharge system based on the zinc–air battery. As shown in Fig. 6 (a), a Zn plate served as the anode, the composite substrate of CoNi–NCNT loaded carbon cloth (2 mg/cm2) and Ni foam as the air cathode (Fig. S14), and 6 M KOH containing 0.2 M zinc acetate as the electrolyte [35]. The open-circuit voltage of CoNi–NCNT was 1.43 V, which is quite close to the 1.45 V of Pt/C–Ir/C (Fig. 6(c) and (d)). To verify the practicability of CoNi–NCNT in Zn–air batteries, we lit a small bulb by connecting two batteries in series (Fig. 6(b)). The discharge and charge polarization curves of CoNi–NCNT and Pt/C–Ir/C are shown in Fig. 6(e), and the corresponding power density plots of the discharge were calculated to evaluate the discharge capacity of CoNi–NCNT. The polarization curves demonstrate that CoNi–NCNT shows better capability during the high current discharge process than Pt/C–Ir/C. The power density limit of CoNi–NCNT is about 88 mW/cm2 at a discharge voltage of 0.69 V, greatly surpassing the 47 mW/cm2 of Pt/C–Ir/C at 0.75 V, which implies its higher discharge speed [36]. Moreover, by normalizing with respect to the mass of consumed Zn, the specific capacity of CoNi–NCNT was calculated as 744.3 mWh/gZn at a constant current of 10 mA/cm2, which is superior to the 711.2 mWh/gZn of Pt/C–Ir/C (Fig. 6(f)). In addition, the charge-discharge cyclic stability of CoNi–NCNT and Pt/C–Ir/C was further characterized at a current density of 10 mA/cm2. As shown in Fig. 6(g), after several initial cycles, the discharging potential of CoNi–NCNT gradually stabilizes at 1.24 V and shows a negligible voltage drop after 100 h of testing (150 cycles, 40 min for charging and discharging in each cycle), whereas Pt/C–Ir/C suffers extreme inactivation after only 18 cycles, which suggests CoNi–NCNT has better recharge ability as an air cathode. 4 Conclusions In summary, the double active site load bifunctional catalyst CoNi–NCNT was prepared by pyrolyzing melamine, cobalt nitrate, and nickel nitrate on CNT, and CoNi–NCNT proved to be a superior bifunctional electrocatalyst for both the ORR and OER. Based on a series of comparison experiments, we concluded that the ORR catalytic activity derived mainly from the Co–N–C structure, and the introduction of Ni further improved catalytic performance by adjusting the electron cloud density and spin density of Co/Ni–N–C. Furthermore, CoNi alloy particles endowed CoNi–NCNT with satisfactory OER catalytic activity, and then, compared with monometallic doping, the alloy particles showed higher activity and stability because of the synergistic effect. Moreover, the superior specific capacity of 744.3 mAh/gZn, peak power density of 88 mW/cm2, and excellent rechargeable cycling stability obtained from Zn–air batteries testing indicated that CoNi–NCNT achieved satisfactory performance. More hopefully, a reasonable explanation concerning the active sites for the ORR and OER, realized by a series of comparison tests, provide constructive guidance for designing a higher activity bifunctional catalyst. coredata.dc:description: The development of bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts with high efficiency, high stability, and low cost is of great significance to the industrialization of rechargeable Zn–air batteries. A widely accepted view is that the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) follow different catalytic mechanisms, and accordingly they need different active sites for catalysis. Transition metal elements have admirable electronic acceptance ability for coordinating with reactants, and this can weaken the bond energy between reactants, thus promoting the ORR or OER reactions. Herein, the ORR and OER activities of different transition metal supported nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes were systematically studied and compared. The optimal catalyst for synchronous ORR and OER was obtained by pyrolyzing melamine, cobalt nitrate, and nickel nitrate on carbon nanotubes, called cobalt–nickel supported nitrogen-mixed carbon nanotubes (CoNi–NCNT), which were equipped with two types of high-performance active sites—the Co/Ni–N–C structure for the ORR and CoNi alloy particles for the OER—simultaneously. Remarkably, the optimized CoNi–NCNT exhibited a satisfactory bifunctional catalytic activity for both the ORR and OER. The value of the oxygen electrode activity parameter, ΔE, of CoNi–NCNT was 0.81 V, which surpasses that of catalysts Pt/C and Ir/C, and most of the non-precious metal-based bifunctional electrocatalysts reported in previous literatures. Furthermore, a specially assembled rechargeable Zn–air cell with CoNi–NCNT loaded carbon paper as an air cathode was used to evaluate the practicability. As a result, a superior specific capacity of 744.3 mAh/gZn, a peak power density of 88 mW/cm2, and an excellent rechargeable cycling stability were observed, and these endow the CoNi–NCNT with promising prospects for practical application.

coredata.dc:title: Ni–Co bimetallic coordination effect for long lifetime rechargeable Zn–air battery
